official-title.#text:
To enhance consumer access to electricity information and allow for the adoption of innovative
			 products and services to help consumers manage their energy usage.

cosponsor.#tail: ) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Access to Consumer Energy Information Act
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Access to Consumer Energy Information Act
E-Access Act

text.#text: In this Act, the term

header.#text: Consumer access to electric energy information

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall encourage and support the adoption of policies that allow electricity consumers
			 access to their own electricity data.

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Section 362(d) of the Energy Policy and Conservation Act
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Energy Policy and Conservation Act/s:362/ss:d
Energy Policy and Conservation Act/s:362/ss:d/p:16

text.#text: in

quote.#tail: after the semicolon at the end;

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Energy Policy and Conservation Act/s:362/ss:d/p:17
Energy Policy and Conservation Act/s:362/ss:d/p:18

text.#text: by redesignating

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Energy Policy and Conservation Act/s:362/ss:d/p:16

text.#text: by inserting after
programs—

to enhance consumer access to and understanding of energy usage and price information, including
			 consumers’ own residential and commercial electricity information; and

to allow for the development and adoption of innovative products and services to assist consumers
			 in managing energy consumption and expenditures; and

header.#text: Voluntary guidelines for electric consumer access

text.#text: In this subsection:
the electric energy consumption of an electric consumer over a defined time period;

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Access to Consumer Energy Information Act/s:3/ss:c/p:1/sp:A/cl:i

text.#text:
the retail electric energy prices or rates applied to the electricity usage for the defined time
			 period described in

the estimated cost of service by the consumer, including (if smart meter usage information is
			 available) the estimated cost of service since the last billing cycle of
			 the consumer; and

in the case of nonresidential electric meters, any other electrical information that the meter is
			 programmed to record (such as demand measured in kilowatts, voltage,
			 frequency, current, and power factor).
The term

measures electric energy consumption by an electric consumer at the home or facility of the
			 electric consumer in intervals of 1 hour or less; and

is capable of sending electric energy usage information through a communications network to the
			 electric utility; or

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Access to Consumer Energy Information Act/s:3/ss:c/p:2

text.#text: meets the guidelines issued under

term.#tail: means the device used by an electric utility that—

text.#text: The term

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Access to Consumer Energy Information Act/s:3/ss:c/p:2/sp:B

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall issue voluntary guidelines that establish model standards
			 for implementation of retail electric energy information access in States.

text.#text: Not later than 180 days after the date of enactment of this Act, subject to
consult with—

State and local regulatory authorities, including the National Association of Regulatory Utility
			 Commissioners;

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: National Institute of Standards and Technology

text.#text: other appropriate Federal agencies, including the
consumer and privacy advocacy groups;
utilities;
the National Association of State Energy Officials; and

other appropriate entities, including groups representing commercial and residential building
			 owners and groups that represent demand response and electricity data
			 devices and services; and
provide notice and opportunity for comment.
Before issuing the voluntary guidelines, the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall, to the maximum extent practicable, be
			 guided by actions taken by State and local regulatory authorities to
			 ensure electric consumer access to retail electric energy information,
			 including actions taken after consideration of the standard established
			 under

text.#text: In issuing the voluntary guidelines, the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
section 111(d)(17) of the Public Utility Regulatory Policies Act of
			 1978
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Public Utility Regulatory Policies Act of 1978/s:111/ss:d/p:17

text.#text: the timeliness and specificity of retail electric energy information;
appropriate nationally recognized open standards for data;

the protection of data security and electric consumer privacy, including consumer consent
			 requirements; and

issues relating to access of electric energy information for owners and managers of multitenant
			 commercial and residential buildings.

The voluntary guidelines shall provide guidance on issues necessary to carry out this subsection,
			 including—

retail electric energy information should be made available to electric consumers (and third-party
			 designees of the electric consumers) in the United States—

in an electronic machine readable form, without additional charge, in conformity with standards
			 developed through a voluntary, consensus-based, multistakeholder process;
in as close to real-time as is reasonably practicable;

at the level of specificity that the data is transmitted by the meter or as is reasonably
			 practicable; and

in a manner that provides adequate protections for the security of the information and the privacy
			 of the electric consumer;

electric utilities should, when a smart meter is servicing a consumer, communicate energy usage
			 information to a device or network of an electric consumer or a device or
			 network of a third party authorized by the consumer, and where feasible
			 should provide to the consumer or third-party designee, at a minimum,
			 access to usage information (not including price information) of the
			 consumer directly from the smart meter in as close to real-time as is
			 reasonably practicable;

retail electric energy information of the consumer should be made available to the consumer through
			 a website or other electronic access authorized by the electric consumer,
			 for a period of at least 13 months after the date on which the usage
			 occurred;

consumer access to data, including data provided to owners and managers of commercial and
			 multifamily buildings with multiple tenants, should not interfere with or
			 compromise the integrity, security, or privacy of the operations of a
			 utility and the electric consumer;

electric energy information relating to usage information generated by devices in or on the
			 property of the consumer that is transmitted to the electric utility
			 should be made available to the electric consumer or the third-party agent
			 designated by the electric consumer; and

the same privacy and security requirements applicable to the contracting utility should apply to
			 third-party agents contracting with a utility to process the customer data
			 of that utility.
The voluntary guide­lines shall include guidance that—

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall periodically review and, as necessary, revise the voluntary guidelines to
			 reflect changes in technology, privacy needs, and the market for electric
			 energy and services.
